awd_titl_txt: Literacy, Education, and Language Processing: Special Sessions at the Human Sentence Processing 2023 Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Language is vital in everyday life. The field of psycholinguistics seeks to understand the cognitive mechanisms of language comprehension and production. It examines how working memory, attention, world knowledge, and learning systems affect language use. But, much research in this field has relied on literate, university-educated samples. Scientific theories have not been tested across the full range of language and literacy skills. This gap makes it harder for educators to use psycholinguistic research to improve language-related education. There is a clear need to unite research and researchers in psycholinguistics with those in education and literacy. This project supports a special session at the 2023 Annual Conference on Human Sentence processing. The session highlights connections between psycholinguistics, educational psychology, and educational technology. The session will help describe how language processing is shaped by formal education and literacy. It will also characterize how we can use our knowledge of human language processing in education.

This special conference session is titled "Literacy, Education, and Language Processing." It will be held at the 2023 Annual Conference on Human Sentence Processing at the University of Pittsburgh. The HSP conference is formerly known as the CUNY Sentence Processing Conference. It has been the top psycholinguistics conference in North America for decades. About 400 people attend the three-day conference. The conference includes about 35 oral and 150 poster presentations selected from over 300 abstracts. As part of the special session, six invited speakers will discuss the interface of psycholinguistics with literacy and education. They will talk about (1) how formal education and literacy may alter language processing, (2) how students experiencing a nonstandard dialect at home may be disadvantaged by the burden of adapting to the language of formal education, and (3) how educational technology can quantify language experience and attainment. The project helps train junior scientists with discounted registration, need-based travel stipends, and junior researcher awards. The project broadens participation in the field by inviting minority-serving institutions to a livestream of the special session talks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a special session on “Literacy, Education, and Language Processing” at the 2023 Annual Conference on Human Sentence Processing, held March 9-11, 2023, at the University of Pittsburgh.  The special session encouraged connections between psycholinguistics, literacy, and education and included presentations from six eminent researchers who bridge these fields:

  • Dr. Suzanne Adlof (Associate Professor of Communication Sciences, University of South Carolina)
  • Dr. Becky Xi Chen (Professor of Applied Psychology and Human Development, University of Toronto)
  • Dr. Kiel Christianson (Professor of Educational Psychology, Psychology, and Linguistics, University of Illinois)
  • Dr. Scott Crossley (Professor of Applied Linguistics and Learning Sciences, Vanderbilt University)
  • Dr. Ariel James (Assistant Professor of Psychology, Macalaster University)
  • Dr. Charles Perfetti (Distinguished University Professor of Psychology and Linguistics and Director of the Learning Research and Development Center, University of Pittsburgh)

Dr. Christianson and Dr. Rachel Romeo (Assistant Professor of Hearing and Speech Sciences, University of Maryland) hosted a panel discussion to discuss, debate, and synthesize advances from the special session.

Beyond our invited speakers, we received 343 submissions and accepted 272 posters (192 in-person and 80 online) and 25 talks. Of these accepted submissions, 70 pertained to the special session. 279 individuals, from across the United States and over 20 other countries, attended in person. An additional 468 individuals attended remotely, for a total of 747 attendees.

To broaden participation in these activities, we offered a substantial student discount on registration fees and gave out 32 need-based travel awards and 28 waivers of registration fees.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Language is vital in everyday life. The field of psycholinguistics seeks to understand the cognitive mechanisms of language comprehension and production. It examines how working memory, attention, world knowledge, and learning systems affect language use. But, much research in this field has relied on literate, university-educated samples.  Scientific theories have not been tested across the full range of language and literacy skills. This gap makes it harder for educators to use psycholinguistic research to improve language arts and second language education.

To address this gap, our special session highlighted connections between psycholinguistics, educational psychology, and educational technology. Our six invited scientists spoke to effects of literacy and print exposure on language processing and/or effects of language exposure on literacy, consequences of dialect variation for language processing and education, educational and language technology that can be used to quantify individual differences and text features, and language difficulties, impairments, and disabilities.

These speakers spanned departments of communication sciences, education, human development, applied linguistics, and psychology. Their research draws on a variety of languages and methodologies, ranging from cognitive neuroscience, to educational interventions, to eye-tracking, to computational linguistics.

The special session also capitalized and built on the unique strengths of the Pittsburgh academic community, which including the Learning Research and Development Center, an interdisciplinary institute dedicated to the science of learning and to education practice.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

Translation of Psycholinguistic Research. The special session presented a valuable step towards translating language science into educational contexts. We believe that research on sentence processing, and language processing more broadly, has substantial value for both first- and second-language education. It can also be applied to improve educational materials, such as constructing effective educational texts, including those that refute scientific misconceptions or misinformation. To date, however, this type of basic-science, laboratory research typical has had only modest impact on educational practice, in part because this work has often proceeded in isolation from scholars in education and other fields. Our project helped address this gap: We invited six speakers who spoke directly on the interface of literacy, education, and language processing; we solicited and highlighted additional, submitted talks and presentations on this same theme; and we hosted a panel discussion near the end of conference on the implications of sentence processing research for teaching and educational experiences.

Training of Junior Scientists.  Students received discounted registration, and many were awarded travel stipends and/or waivers of conference fees supported by the award.  For students unable to attend in person, we offered one online poster session and a livestream of the talks. Two junior scientists received the Gibson/Fedorenko Junior Researcher Award of $1,000 each.

Outreach to Under-represented Minorities. We reached out to minority-serving institutions to solicit conference submissions and to advertise the livestream. We met remotely with these students for a pre-conference discussion of the speakers’ work and what they are likely to talk about, and we met again following the conference to debrief.

Speed Mentoring Event. We hosted a speed mentoring event organized by Dr. Michelle Colvin (Teaching Assistant Professor of Psychology, University of Pittsburgh). Conference attendees could enroll for free, and we matched prospective mentors and mentees among 139 participants.

Training of Graduate Students. Graduate students at the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie Mellon University supported the planning and implementation of the conference.
